summary: The document outlines the detailed and sensitive process of establishing a credible cover story for William J. Acch's transition from the Economic Cooperation Administration (ECA) to the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), with an intended overseas assignment for the CPC. It highlights the involvement of Leo Cherne from the Research Institute of America in supporting Acch's cover story for a limited duration, showcasing the intricate planning and coordination required for intelligence operations. The communications span several years, reflecting the ongoing adjustments and meticulous efforts to ensure the plausibility and security of the cover arrangements.
key_findings: A credible cover story was meticulously developed for William J. Acch's transition from ECA to CIA, involving his resignation and an overseas assignment with CPC.
Leo Cherne of the Research Institute of America played a crucial role in backstopping Acch's cover story, agreeing to support the narrative temporarily.
The document underscores the complexity and sensitivity of creating plausible employment backgrounds for intelligence operatives, involving external organizations.
The prolonged process of securing and adjusting cover arrangements illustrates the detailed planning and coordination inherent in intelligence operations.
keywords: President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Act of 1992
